title: Do real life detectives actually do the kind of detective work that is depicted on TV? - Quora

response.answer_text: There have been a couple of TV shows that try to mostly get it right, but damned few. Mostly, it’s boring “leg work”…. Finding and interviewing witnesses and suspects, talking to “snitches”, waiting for lab work to come back, and constantly documenting the investigation. Often it takes weeks or months to “develop a suspect” and then you want all your evidentiary ducks in a row before ever bringing the suspect in to be formally interrogated. In “dramady” cop shows like Bones or Castle… The investigators always talk the suspect into a full confession without any of the required protections…. Absurd.

In the UK, no, not really. The DCs I work with largely deal with a portfolio of jobs, usually several assaults, sexual assaults and rapes. Forensic work is sent off and comes back a couple of weeks later; the detectives don't go to the lab often. They largely interview suspects and witnesses and sometimes conduct house searches. In my town we have 2 or 3 murders a year and most of our detectives get involved in these. They rarely run after anyone. They do tend to work long hours when on a job and marriages tend to suffer. There are not many donuts but cakes are fairly plentiful.

Detective work is a lot of leg work, searching for people, examining evidence all while trying to solve a case or build one against a suspect(s). It can be difficult yet very rewarding. Long hours, frustrating dead ends, possible steak outs, and tons of paperwork are very common. I had the opportunity to work in patrol, traffic, and the Detective Bureau and never found any police duty or function that is accurately portrayed on TV or in the movies.

You ever notice on those home improvement shows how they remodel some home in 30 minutes. Same as investigations. One or two people do all the work. All the subs show up on time and don't get in the way of each other. It's the only project any of them are working on. They leave out all the bent nails, wrong materials, bad cuts, bad measurements, permit issues, trash, etc. Somehow they compress a 6 month project into 30 minutes. Kind of like that but more screwed up.

No, of course not. E.g., in many real murders, the murderer is sitting on a chair next to the body when the police arrive and says, “Yep, I shot the bastard.” How are you going to make a sixty minute show about that? If crimes are not solved within 48 hours, or they usually are never solved. A great book about real detectives is Homicide: A Year on the Killing Streets by David Simon.

Even in reality TV nothing is as it appears. There are hours upon hours police reports, follow-ups and leads to follow up. I enjoyed the time I spent as a detective but found myself returning back to the streets where my true enjoyment for helping people and catching bad guys was satisfied daily.
